D. degree from the Shivaji University, Maharashtra, India in 2010. She has completed her postdoctoral Research at National University of Singapore, Singapore under Overseas Postdoctoral Fellowship scheme of SERB, Govt. of India in 2017. She is currently working as Assistant Professor in the Department of Technology, Shivaji University, Kolhapur. Her research interest includes design and synthesis of Coordination Polymers/MOFs for sensing, catalysis and energy applications. Graphical abstract The progress and advancement of machine learning techniques for performance prediction (Capacitance, RUL) of supercapacitor using synthetic & operational conditions and structural features are discussed. Supercapacitors are appealing energy storage devices for their promising features like high power density, outstanding cycling stability, and a quick charge–discharge cycle. The exceptional life cycle and ultimate power capability of supercapacitors are needed in the transportation and renewable energy generation sectors. Hence, predicting the capacitance and lifecycle of supercapacitors is significant for selecting the suitable material and planning replacement intervals for supercapacitors. In addition, system failures can be better addressed by accurately forecasting the lifecycle of SCs. Recently, the use of machine learning for performance prediction of energy storage materials has drawn increasing attention from researchers globally because of its superiority in prediction accuracy, time efficiency, and cost-effectiveness. This article presents a detailed review of the progress and advancement of ML techniques for the prediction of capacitance and remaining useful life (RUL) of supercapacitors. The review starts with an introduction to supercapacitor materials and ML applications in energy storage devices, followed by workflow for ML model building for supercapacitor materials. Then, the summary of machine learning applications for the prediction of capacitance and RUL of different supercapacitor materials including EDLCs (carbon based materials), pesudocapacitive (oxides and composites) and hybrid materials is presented. Finally, the general perspective for future directions is also presented. Keywords Supercapacitors Energy storage materials Artificial neural network Machine learning Capacitance prediction Remaining useful life 1 Introduction Supercapacitors (SCs) or electrochemical capacitors (ECs) are encouraging energy storage devices (ESD) due to promising features such as high power density, excellent cycling stability, and fast charge–discharge cycle [1–4]. SCs are appealing for applications that generate renewable energy because of their exceptional cycle life and superior power capabilities. Based on the energy storage mechanism, SCs are generally categorized into electrochemical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs), pseudocapacitors, and hybrid capacitors [5]. EDLCs store energy by physical adsorption of ions at the electrolyte–electrode interface, and the electrode materials used are carbon-based materials like activated carbons (ACs), CNTs, carbon aerogels, etc. [6]. However, metal oxides and conducting polymers are suitable candidates for pseudocapacitors, which store charges using reversible redox processes [7]. Compared with EDLCs, pseudocapacitive materials exhibit high specific capacitance. Although carbon-based materials have comparatively low specific capacitance, they have better cycle stability and rate capability. However, hybrid supercapacitors are composed of a capacitive-and battery-like material as a negative and positive electrode [8]. Machine learning (ML) techniques are emergent alternative tools to solve a wide variety of scientific and engineering issues. In machine learning, systems learn from past experimental data and existing knowledge to establish ML models for prediction. Recently, ML techniques have received tremendous attention for their effective prediction of physical and chemical properties [9,10], high-throughput screening for crystal structure prediction [11–13], discovering structure and properties relationship [14] and hastening chemical synthesis of high-performance materials [15–17]. A growing amount of emphasis has been paid to the use of ML models to forecast material properties accurately. Because the predicted information by ML not only reveals the properties of tested materials, but provides directions for future experiments. The recent advancements of ML applications in material science facilitate the design, discovery, and optimization of new energy-efficient materials [18–22]. The ML technology helps to improve accuracy, save time, and expedite the exploration of energy materials. In the last couple of years, some excellent reviews associated with ML applications for the development of ESDs have appeared in the literature [23–33]. For example, Chen et al. [27] introduced ML applications for property prediction and materials development for energy storage and conversion systems such as catalysis, Li-ion batteries, solar cells, CO2 capture, etc. Guan et al. [28] presented a thorough review of the applications of ML-based atomic simulations for material discovery and property prediction. The review demonstrated the use of ML model to assess the thermodynamics and kinetics of Si, LiC, and LiTiO systems. Ziheng Lu [29] discussed use of ML for energy devices including batteries, photovoltaics, and catalysts. Methodological advances in high throughput screening, structure prediction, and design optimization are also discussed. Barret and Haruna [30] highlighted the latest developments in artificial intelligence and ML for targeted battery energy storage solutions. Liu et al. [31] provided a comprehensive review of the recent developments in ML applications for alkaline-ion battery, photovoltaics, catalytic, and CO2 capture materials. In another review, the authors [32] summarized the application of ML models for designing rechargeable battery materials by mining structure–property relations for different electrolytes and electrode materials. C. Liu et al. [33] reviewed model-based and data-based forecasting of remaining useful life (RUL) and state-of-charge (SOC) of supercapacitors. The author discussed and compared many research approaches for supercapacitor's SOC estimation and RUL forecasting. Most of these reviews are directed toward ML applications in energy storage devices specifically batteries, photovoltaics, etc. However, a detailed overview of ML applications for supercapacitor materials is still lacking. Therefore, herein we provide a detailed review of the progress and advancement of ML techniques for the development of supercapacitor materials. The structure of this review is organized as: First, a typical workflow for ML model building for supercapacitor materials is provided, including the steps involved in this process. Then, the actual application of ML techniques for capacitance prediction and lifetime prediction of supercapacitor materials is fully reviewed. We mainly highlight the advancement of ML techniques in discovering the influence of the structure and properties on capacitive performance and lifetime prediction of the different supercapacitors materials including EDLCs (carbon based materials), pesudocapacitive (oxides and composites) and hybrid materials. Finally, we conclude with primary findings and general perspectives for future directions. 2 Workflow of machine learning Prediction or classification of materials with the ML model mainly depends on the collection of the dataset, the selection of specific features, and the set of algorithms used for the ML model. A typical workflow for ML model building is presented in Fig. 1 . The steps involved are elaborated in detail as follows. 2.1 Data collection Data collection is the initial step in training the ML model. A large, sufficient, and representative dataset with an appropriately trained ML model can make predictions with higher accuracy. Large datasets needed for experimentation come from open source databases (ChEMBL, ICSD, OQMD, COD, etc.), and projects like the materials genome initiative. Materials' electrical, optical, and mechanical properties are obtained with these databases. For the prediction of the performance of supercapacitors, source datasets are generally collected from experimentations, scientific publications or computer calculations. Pre-processing of data is required to identify missing or incorrect data and to replace, revise, or remove it from the collected data [34–36]. The effectiveness of ML algorithms in material science relies on the amount and quality of available data for the training of ML models. 2.2 Feature engineering Feature engineering consists of selecting specific properties or features of the materials and transforming raw data into desired features or quantitative parameters that accurately predict or classify data. Feature engineering includes feature extraction, correlation degree calculation, data dimension reduction, and feature selection. The majority of the feature extraction approaches in ML applications for supercapacitor materials rely on human decision-making. However in some cases, algorithm such as principal component analysis (PCA) is used for dimensionality reduction. For predicting the supercapacitor's performance, synthesis conditions (precursor type, activation temperature and type), structural properties of supercapacitor materials (composition, morphology, specific surface area (SSA), pore volume (PV), pore size (PS), I D/I G, doping elements, etc.) and operational properties (power window (PW), current density, electrolyte type and concentration, etc.) are used as input features for training ML models. 2.3 ML model selection Machine learning techniques are categorized as supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement learning, and ensemble learning. The selection of the best ML model with an appropriate training dataset leads to high prediction accuracy. Supervised learning models like artificial neural network (ANN), support vector machine (SVM), decision tree (DT), multi-layer perceptron (MLP), random forest (RF), linear regression (LR), recurrent neural network (RNN), and Gaussian process regression (GPR) are commonly used in material science. Most of the earlier studies efficiently predict supercapacitor performance with ANN and RNN models. Neural networks are used for the classification and regression of continuous target attributes, whereas RNN is used for handling sequential or time-series data. Further, deep neural networks like MLP are used to achieve better performance of supercapacitors. Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks are RNNs that use sequence forecast issues to learn order dependency. LSTMs have feedback connections that differentiate them from more traditional feedforward neural networks. Fig. 2 shows various types of ML algorithms. 2.4 ML model evaluation The selected models need to be assessed for optimization and ultimate selection of the best model. The precision of the ML model relies on the correct prediction of output in the test dataset. ML models are evaluated and verified for their prediction results with performance metrics like R, correlation coefficient (R 2), root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), mean square error (MSE), mean absolute percentage error (MAPE), and error rate. Along with the parameters, every ML model possesses hyper-parameters that affect its performance. Hence, hyper-parameters are optimized to avoid underfitting and overfitting using cross validation, particle swarm optimization (PSO), genetic algorithm (GA), etc. Further, using the best suitable ML model, prediction of performance, material screening, process optimization, etc. is achieved. 3 Application of ML for supercapacitors The application of ML in energy storage materials, especially for supercapacitors has been successful in recent years. The core metrics used to evaluate the performance of supercapacitors are capacitance, resistance, cycle life, energy density, power density, etc. However, researchers are more concerned with predicting capacitance and lifecycles of supercapacitor due to its significance for selecting suitable supercapacitor materials, planning replacement intervals for supercapacitors, and determining the operating conditions. In this section, the applications of ML for predicting the capacitance and RUL along with other properties such as energy density and power density of different supercapacitor materials including EDLCs, pesudocapacitive and hybrid materials are discussed. 3.1 ML for capacitance prediction of supercapacitors Porous carbon materials (PCMs) having a large SSA, porosity, conductivity, and high thermal stability are generally considered suitable candidates for EDLC supercapacitor materials. Structural parameters (i.e. SSA, porosity, pore distribution, nature of dopant and its concentration, etc.) and operational parameters (i.e. electrolyte type, electrolyte concentration, potential window, etc.) have non-linear impact on the performance of the supercapacitors [37–40]. In recent years, ML models have been adopted to understand the correlation of structural and operational parameters with performance of carbon-based supercapacitors like ACs, biomass-derived activated carbon (BACs) and heteroatom-doped carbon materials. Zhou et al. [41] presented four regression models, ANN, RF, SVM, and generalized linear regression (GLR) for predicting the necessary properties of ACs to get the highest energy and power density. For training the models, surface area of micro- and mesopores, and scan rate are used as input parameters, however, capacitance and power density are output parameters. ANN model shows better performance in capacitance prediction of activated carbon and also provides a better correlation with predicted and experimental power density. Furthermore, ANN model estimates that maximum energy density can be achieved for ACs with a surface area of 920 m2/g for micropores and 770 m2/g for mesopores, respectively. Su et al. [42] explored the effect of solvent properties in electrolytes on the capacitance of EDLCs. The experimental data including a range of diameters, viscosities, dipole moments, dielectric constants, boiling temperature, and frequency dependent capacitance for different solvents are used as input to train ML models. ML models such as SVR, MLP, M5 model tree (M5P), M5 rule (M5R), and LR are used for the experimentation of capacitance. Among the five models, MLP, M5R, and M5P, perform superior to the SVR and LR. ML model result indicates that the solvent type and dielectric constant significantly influence EDL capacitance; however, dipole moment, viscosity, and boiling temperature slightly affect EDL capacitance. Liu et al. [43] designed a new strategy for forecasting the capacitive performance of PCMs by investigating the correlation between structural properties and capacitance. For capacitance prediction of PCMs, 105 sets of different PCMs with 11 structural features SSA, PV, PS, the surface area of mesopore (S meso) and micropore (S micro), mesopore (V meso) and micropore volume (V micro), etc. were obtained. Three ensemble models including RF, gradient boosting machines (GBM), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were utilized to predict capacitance in addition to supervised learning models such as ANN, SVM, and multiple linear regression (MLR) (Fig. 3 a-d). The result indicates that the ensemble XGBoost model exhibits the better prognosis performance of SCs with R, RMSE, and MAE values, 0.892, 25.50, and 19.56, respectively. Fig. 3(c) depicts the importance of structural features (SSA, S micro/SSA, S meso, PS and V meso/PV) toward the capacitive performance of PCMs. Within a coarse-grained framework, Yang et al. [44] used the classical density functional theory (CDFT) to investigate the capacitance and interfacial behaviour of spherical EDL capacitors. Using electrode curvature, surface potential, and electrode concentration, the regression tree (RT) model calculates capacitive performance. For screening porous and innovative electrodes, the suggested model combines CDFT and RT techniques. The CDFT predicts the ion distributions and mean electrostatic potentials of the EDLCs. The electrolyte content and particle curvature have a positive relationship with the EDL capacitance. Further, the M5P model, a version of RT, can predict capacitance performance quite precisely. Saad et al. [45] utilized k-nearest neighbors' regression, Bayesian ridge regression, DT and ANN models for accurate forecasting of graphene's capacitance using different electrochemical and physiochemical features of graphene. ANN model performs better than the other three models. Lu et al. [46] presented ANN model for forecasting capacitance of the carbonized metal–organic framework (C-ZIF-67). Experimental and ANN predicted capacitances are compared indicating that the proposed ANN model shows better performance for SC capacitance prediction with the lowest error (0.02%–1.05%). Biomass wastes such as algae, orange peel, sugarcane, rice, wheat straw, coconut shell, etc. are considered a good precursor for the production of BACs for supercapacitor application due to their advanced structural properties, environmental friendliness, sustainability, and cost-effectiveness. Preparation of BACs is a two-stage process, carbonization coupled with physical and chemical activation. The precursor type and the activation process can influence the electrochemical performance of activated carbon electrode material significantly. Therefore, several efforts have been made for process optimization and performance prediction of BACs as supercapacitor electrode using ML application. For instance, Ma's group [47] proposed an ANN model to investigate the effect of biomass components and structural features of algae-based ACs on the performance of supercapacitors. A data set of 200 BACs from literature with input features such as SSA, PS, PV, V meso, V mic, I D/I G, resistance (R s), aspect ratio, cellulose ratio, and nitrogen content (N (%)) was selected to train the model. Levenberg–Marquart Back-Propagation (LM-BP) algorithm is applied to predict the capacitance of the supercapacitor. The model gives an accurate forecast of the specific capacitance with a low MSE and a high R 2 value. Furthermore, the relative importance of the input feature to the capacitance is evaluated using the RF algorithm. The result indicates the SSA, R s and PV play a significant role in capacitance prediction with a weightage of 30.1%, 19.4%, and 18.7%, respectively. Thus, the proposed ANN model gives directions for modifying the bio-carbon structure for future supercapacitor material. Mathew et al. [48] applied the ML technique for the process optimization of activated carbon electrodes derived from Jackfruit seeds. For multiobjective process optimization, an ANN model combined with Derringer's desirability function and PSO algorithm is used. Using the combined approach optimal conditions of temperature, impregnation ratio, and percentage of activated carbon are demonstrated to get the supercapacitor electrode with high capacitance and low resistance. Rahimi et al. [49] utilized the ANN model to explore the impact of synthesis conditions, structural properties and operational condition on the capacitance of the BAC supercapacitor. Fourteen input variables from 101 datasets were selected from the activation procedure, structural properties of BACs, electrode preparation procedures, and operational conditions for training of the model. As a result, the proposed radial basis function (RBF) model accurately predicts performance with 0.99 and 0.24 values for R 2 and MAPE, respectively. In addition, the sensitivity analysis demonstrated the significance of structural features of BACs, electrolyte concentration, binder ratio, and activation agent ratio on capacitance performance. Wikramaarachchi et al. [50] presented ML-based prediction model for the energy storage performance of the BACs derived from mango seed husk. The data of synthesis conditions, the structural and electro-chemical features collected from experimented measurements are used for the prediction of capacitance. The input variables, activation temperature, SSA, I D/I G ratio, PV, average pore diameter, and current density are used to train the model. Among the different ML models (DT, LR, SVR and MLP), the MLP model gives superior results with the only marginal difference between the predicted and experimental data with values R 2 (0.9868), MSE (4.1651), and MAE (1.5741). Yang et al. [51] presented an ML-based model for predicting electrochemical performance of biomass derived biochar materials using four ML algorithms ANN, DT, RF and XGBoost. Nine input parameters including activation conditions (activator ratio, activation temperature and time) and biochar properties (C/O, C/N, atom and SSA) and capacitance test conditions were used to train the ML models. The DT and XGBoost model performs well with the high R 2 and low error. Further, the importance of input features was investigated using DT and XGBoost model indicating that activator ratio, activation time and SSA along with C/N, and C/O are important features for forecasting biochar capacitance. Mohan et al. [52] proposed a feedforward BPNN model for supercapacitive prediction of energy storage materials for the chemical activation process and electrochemical process. Three input parameters, carbon/chemical mass ratio, temperature and time, and surface area as output parameter are used for chemical activation process. However, for the electrochemical process, electrolyte, current density and PW are input parameters and specific capacitance is an output parameter. Surface area and specific capacitance are key metrics predicted by the ANN (LMBP) model. The model gives better performance for both processes with R 2 (0.992, 0.9789) and MSE (0.002892, 0.006884). The capacitive performance of carbon-based materials is further enhanced by the chemical doping of heteroatoms such as boron, nitrogen, sulphur, phosphorus, etc. [53–56]. Therefore, efforts have also been diverted towards the use of ML models for forecasting the performance of supercapacitors considering the influence of % doping elements along with other structural and operational parameters. Zhu et al. [57] used machine learning models like ANN, LR, and Lasso for the capacitance prediction of carbon materials. A data set comprising 681 carbon-based supercapacitors is collected from more than 300 publications. Five input features: SSA, PS, I D/I G, N-doping level, and voltage window is selected for training the ML model. It is demonstrated that the ANN model works better with R 2 value of 0.91 than LR and Lasso models. Su et al. [58] investigated the effect of heteroatom doping composition and structural features of carbon materials on capacitance performance using ML algorithms. A total of 121 sets of carbon-based supercapacitors with input parameters including SSA, PV, PS, PW, I D/I G, % N-doping, and % O-doping are collected from the literature for training ML models. Among four ML models, LR, SVR, MLP, and RT used to predict the capacitance, MLP and RT models show improved performance with RMSE of 67.62 and 68.45, respectively (Fig. 4 a). As shown in Fig. 4(b), the MLP model also generates relative contribution of each input parameter towards capacitance. The SSA and PV have the most decisive influence on capacitance performance, with a weight of 30.1% and 24.1%, respectively. Zhou et al. [59] investigated the influence of the heteroatom doping configuration of carbon electrodes on capacitance and retention rate using ML models. Supercapacitor performance is measured by carbon electrodes' capacitance and power density in 6 M KOH electrolytes. Eight input parameters including structural properties of carbon materials (Surface area of micro- and mesopores), the chemical compositions of N/O co-doping, and the scan rates in cyclic voltammetry measurements are used for training the model. Four different ML models, GLR, SVM, RF, and ANN are used to unveil the impact of structural characteristics and surface composition of N/O co-doped carbon electrodes on the performance of supercapacitors. Among the ML models used, ANN performs better for the prediction of capacitance and power density with a high value of R 2 and low error. Furthermore, according to ANN model, the best N/O co-doped carbon electrode will have the energy density that is comparable to a commercial battery but with a significantly greater power density. Fallah et al. [60] presented the ANN model to discover the impact of the electrode structure and operating conditions on the capacitance of boron-doped carbon-based materials. Five variables, including boron-doping (%), PS, SSA, voltage window, and electrolyte solution are selected to train the model. Thus, ANN (LM-BP) gives an acceptable predictive performance with low error (∼1.06%). The relative contribution of each input parameter investigated using RF algorithm shows that the electrode surface area, heteroatom doping, and electrolyte type contributed 89.8%. Gheytanzadeh et al. [61] utilized SVM combined with the grey wolf optimization (GWO) algorithm to discover the effect of structural properties on capacitive performance of carbon-based materials. A set of 681 carbon-based supercapacitors with five input features, including SSA, N-doping level, I D/I G ratio, PS, and PW, were collected from more than 300 publications. As a result, the proposed SVM-GWO shows the best performance in prediction with RMSE value of 39.22 and R 2 value of 0.92. Furthermore, sensitivity analysis indicated that the SSA is the most influencing parameter in capacitance prediction. The author also compared the results obtained with the proposed SVM-GWO model and previously developed models from the literature indicating the better performance of the proposed model with lower RMSE and higher value of R2. Oladipo [62] presented an ANN model to forecast the electrochemical performance of N/S co-doped chicken bone-derived bio-carbon. Three-layered ANN model with five input variables comprising sulphur doping (%), nitrogen doping (%), and electrolytic concentration, electrolyte type, and S/N co-doping is used as presented in Fig. 5 (a). The ANN model accurately predicts capacitance performance with R 2, MSE, and desirability function of 0.964, 0.148, and 0.96, respectively. Furthermore, ANN model also predicts energy density and power density which are consistent with experimental results. The RF algorithm and Garson equation are used to evaluate the relative contribution of the input variable on electrochemical performance. Fig. 5(b) demonstrates that electrolyte concentration, type of electrolyte, and S/N co-doping quantity contributed 38%, 31%, and 20%, respectively. The results indicate that the electrolyte type and concentration along with S/N co-doping quantity significantly influence the electrochemical performance of bio-carbon materials. Rahimi et al. [63] investigated the impact of microstructural properties and operational conditions on the capacitance of heteroatom doped ACs using the ANN model. A dataset of 259 N/O co-doped ACs with 15 input features related to microstructural properties, N/O doping configuration and operational conditions are used to train the model. To anticipate electrode material qualities, MLP algorithm is used. The proposed MLP-NN model has the best performance for ACs with high R 2 (0.99), and low RMSE (8.05) and MAPE (2.49) values. Among the numerous variables, the result suggests that microstructural parameters have the greatest impact on specific capacitance. ML techniques are also employed for performance prediction and design optimization of pseudocapacitive supercapacitors including oxides and composite materials. Many researchers have explored ANN model for performance prediction of different pseudocapacitive supercapacitors. For instance, Farasi and Gobal [64] presented ANN model for forecasting the performance of the mixed type of supercapacitor. Input parameters used for the network are crystal size, surface lattice length, exchange current density, and cell current. Output is generated in the form of energy density, utilization, and power density. The data used for training and validation of the model is adopted from the previously proposed Lin numerical model [65]. The results indicate that supercapacitor performance predicted by ANN matches well with predictions based on the Lin numerical model. Dănilă et al. [66] elaborated a feedforward ANN model to predict the power density and energy density of supercapacitor. Three inputs including capacitance, current and temperature of the supercapacitor, and two output values as power density and energy density are used to train the model. ANN is configured with Matlab functions for a precise pattern for supercapacitor behaviour. Similarly, Mathew et al. [67] also presented ANN (LM-BP) model to discover the effect of electrode area on the performance of the hybrid supercapacitor. Hybrid supercapacitor electrodes with MnO2 and activated carbon are designed in rectangular and square shapes with varying areas. Two inputs, the shape, and area of the electrode are used for predicting specific capacitance, equivalent series resistance (ESR), power density, and pulse current of the electrode. The result indicates that rectangular-shaped electrodes show superior properties compared to square-shaped electrodes. The proposed model is reliable for prediction with MSE value of 0.02. Dongale et al. [68] reported ANN-based approach to investigate the electrochemical behavior of the MnO2 supercapacitor electrode. Experimental data including potential and current density as input variables and the cyclic voltammetry performance as an output parameter is used to train the model. In programming process, the prediction power of ANN was optimized using LM-BP algorithm. The proposed ANN (LM-BP) model performs better in predicting the specific capacitance with a low error rate (<2%) for different MnO2 samples when compared with experimental values. Similarly, Lokhande and Chavan [69] investigated the cyclic behaviour of the prepared Ni(OH)2 supercapacitor electrode using the ANN (LM-BP) model. Experimental data obtained from the electrochemical test of the prepared electrode at different scan rates are used for training the ANN model. Specific capacitance is calculated with instantaneous current, active mass, scan rate, and potential window. ANN model shows better performance with a low percentage error of 0.14%. Alimi et al. [70] also utilized ANN (LM-BP) model for accurate prediction of cyclic voltammetry behaviour of MnO2/NiO/ZnO trijunction supercapacitor electrodes with R 2 value of 0.999. Parwaiz et al. studied electrochemical behaviour of Co-doped Ceria/reduced graphene oxide (Co-CeO2/rGO) nanocomposite using ANN and RF algorithms [71]. Three datasets were generated from experimental electrochemical measurements of Co-CeO2/rGO nanocomposite for different doping configurations of Co or graphene oxide at different scan rates. Compared with RF algorithm, ANN performs well with accuracy for regression (R 2 > 0.95) and low RMSE and MAE values for all datasets. Patel et al. [72] developed rGO/ANFs/CNTs composite electrodes using GPR model. Electrode composition, capacitance, Young's modulus, strength, ultimate strain and toughness are the variables used for the model. Initially, the weight % of the electrode materials is determined and afterwards utility function is used to calculate the trade-off between mechanical and electrochemical properties. Further GPR uses initial experimental data to forecast and enhance performance. Then the optimal composition is predicted with the expected acquisition method. The author has presented ML approach for designing structural electrodes. In order to determine the correlation between the points in the design space, GPRs link the response surface anticipated activity with the data sensitivity to each control variable. The GPR avoids the concern of underfitting or overfitting. Kernel function containing correlation and sensitivity with hyperparameters representing the correlation distance and response surface characteristic length. Kernel's functional form is selected from methods like Matern and RBF. The response surface's mean and variance predictions are made using optimized hyperparameters. For optimizing the performance of a supercapacitor electrode, design spaces are selected with upper confidence bound, probability of improvement and expected improvement. Hence the approach is used to discover the best blend of rGO/ANFs/CNTs for structural energy and power. Ghosh et al. [73] demonstrated ML-based prediction and experimental validation of capacitance and cyclic stability of cerium oxynitride supercapacitors. Five hundred eighty-one sets of samples were extracted with eight attributes selected from the material properties (material composition, surface area, and morphology) and operating properties (PW, charge–discharge cycles, capacity retention, etc.). ML-based combined grade and value prediction models are used for capacitance prediction of cerium oxynitride. RF and MLP models are used for both grade and value prediction models. PCA is used for dimensionality reduction. The RF model gives the best results in the prediction of capacitance as authenticated by experimentation (Fig. 6 ). A summary of the literature survey on ML applications for capacitance prediction of supercapacitors is presented in Table 1 . 3.2 ML for RUL prediction of supercapacitors In recent years, supercapacitors have demonstrated their reliability and high efficiency in power management systems (power portable tools, transportation) owing to their excellent cycle life and almost zero maintenance cost. The RUL is one of the vital parameters for evaluating the performance of supercapacitors that determines the safe service life of a supercapacitor [74–76]. The RUL of supercapacitors is predominantly associated with electrode type and the operating conditions (i.e. temperature, potential window, current density, scanning rate, electrolyte, discharging/charging current cycle times, etc.) [77,78]. With careful monitoring of the aging of supercapacitors, a timely replacement can ensure the security and reliability of supercapacitor materials. Hence, precise forecasting of the RUL of supercapacitors is a significant key in the power management system. Recently, several attempts have been made for predicting the lifetime of supercapacitor materials using ML algorithms. Table 2 summarizes the application of ML techniques for RUL prediction of supercapacitors proposed in the literature. Weigert et al. [79] present BP-NN model for the prediction of the life cycle of hybrid supercapacitor used for the hybrid electric vehicle. The BP-NN model uses input as ESR, duty cycle and type of the battery. The model predicts RUL of supercapacitor with the short charge–discharge curve with a R 2 of 0.95 after 4% of average lifetime. This model helps to predict the number of discharge cycles. Based on the Neo-Fuzzy Neuron (NFN) with time series prediction, Soualhi et al. [80] proposed a new approach for forecasting the aging of supercapacitors. To improve the prediction, blended neural networks and fuzzy logic, NFN architecture is used. This nonlinear network receives several inputs but only creates a single output. Supercapacitor time-series measurements are combined with ESR and double layer capacitance to make predictions. The RMSE values of the R S100 for different horizons of prediction vary from 0.0126 to 0.0236. The obtained data demonstrate the projected method's ability to forecast the aging of SCs. Ren et al. [81] proposed three ML models, LR, PCA, and ANN for forecasting the lifecycle of supercapacitors. The author has produced a dataset of 88 commercial SCs that have been cycled using various methodologies. The hyper-parameters have a substantial impact on the ANN model's predicted outcomes. With a 10% test error, the ANN model delivers the best results in early SC lifecycle forecasting when compared with LR (29.5%) and PCA (18.3%) models. Pozo et al. [82] presented an electro-mathematical and ANN-based model for estimating the charge–discharge behavior of supercapacitors for low-power applications. Various characteristic parameters like voltage, time, temperature, moisture, life cycle, leakage resistance and ESR of the supercapacitor are used for training models. The results are tested and validated by various performance measures like RMSE, MAE, MSE and MAPE. The resulting charge–discharge patterns indicated that the ML model provides better performance when compared with the experimental tests. Roman et al. [83] investigated the capacitance fade trend of ECs in an extreme temperature environment (80 °C–200 °C) using the GPR model. ML algorithm predicts degradation trend for ECs cycled at high temperatures outside the manufacturer’s specified range in an oil and gas drilling environment. Four input features temperature, end of charge voltage, nominal capacitance value, and cycle number of nine samples from two commercial manufacturers are selected for training and validation of the GPR algorithm. The GPR algorithm shows a good fit with an average RMSPE of < 2% and MCS of 93%. Wang et al. [84] reported a convolutional neural network model for the prediction of RUL of supercapacitors. Recently, the RNN model based RUL prediction of supercapacitors has gained increasing attention due to its memory function. Zhou et al. [85] demonstrated three RNN models, Simple RNN, LSTM-RNN, and gated recurrent unit RNN (GRU-RNN) for prediction of RUL of supercapacitors. The effect of temperature and voltage on the aging trend of supercapacitors is investigated using degradation mechanism model of supercapacitor. The LSTM-RNN model structure is depicted in Fig. 7 (a). The RNN model is optimized with Adam and Dropout algorithms to break overfitting problems (Fig. 7b and c). The supercapacitor aging test is applied to evaluate the capacity declination circles of supercapacitors. The same conditions of hyper-parameter settings, hidden layer units, and iterations are used for all three models. In comparison with Simple RNN and GRU-RNN, LSTM RNN model performs better in the prediction of RUL of supercapacitor with a high prediction accuracy and robustness. Liu et al. [86] applied a stacked bidirectional LSTM RNN (BLSTM-RNN) model for the prediction of RUL of supercapacitors. The stacked bidirectional RNN model structure is depicted in Fig. 7(d). The BLSTM-RNN uses input data from positive and negative direction, so gives high accuracy when compared with traditional LSTM-RNN. Also, BLSTM-RNN performs better than Bsimple RNN and BGRU-RNN with high accuracy and robustness. In another work, Liu et al. [87] developed a temporal convolutional network (TCN) based model for prediction of RUL of supercapacitors. The developed model showed strong robustness and excellent accuracy in the predicted results when compared with BPNN, LSTM RNN, GRU RNN models as shown in Fig. 7(e and f). Hybrid ML methods, in which different algorithms are combined to achieve better prediction performance have gained increasing attention. Zhou et al. [88] devised a combined HGA-LSTM approach for estimating the RUL of supercapacitors, which is an efficient hybrid genetic algorithm. The proposed method is adaptable for lifecycle prediction of supercapacitor during real-time dynamic cycling. The approach works with untrained data from both online and offline sources. Three techniques, LSTM, GA-LSTM, and HGA-LSTM are explored to predict the RUL of supercapacitor working at a steady stage. As depicted in Fig. 7(g and h), lower RMSE (0.0247) and higher R 2 (0.9997) of HGA-LSTM compared with the other two models indicate high prediction accuracy and robustness of HGA-LSTM model for estimation of RUL of supercapacitors. In addition, when compared to individual HGA or LSTM approaches, the HGA-LSTM strategy reduces time consumption with the entire procedure taking only 3550 s (less than 1 h). Haris et al. [89] predicted the RUL of supercapacitors using the BOHB-DBN approach, a combination of deep belief network (DBN) with Bayesian optimization and HyperBand (BOHB). With a percent error ranging from 0.05%–2.2% and RMSE (0.8851–1.6326), the projected model is reasonably accurate. Multiple layered restricted Boltzmann machine builds DBN. The author proposes the BOHB method to improve the model's hyperparameters to acquire superior performance from the DBN forecast model. The suggested model's performance criteria are defined using the RMSE. In contrast to earlier research, the suggested model can save 54% of the time in model building. With a minimum RMSE of 1.16, the BOHB-DBN approach demonstrated good forecast accuracy when trained on noisy data. Haris et al. [90] also presented non-dominated search genetic algorithm III and a non-linear autoregressive network with exogenous inputs (NARX) RNN for forecasting the state of health of SCs. The proposed model enhances the performance as compared to LSTM RNN and ANN with low RMSE. Houlian and Gongbo [91] present a method with a combination of BPNN and Kalman filtering algorithm to predict the SOC of SCs. Experimentation shows that the proposed algorithm gives MAE less than 6% in simulations and experiments. BPNN with Kalman filtering algorithm is compared with simulators for the two different conditions as temperature and size of training data for NewYork bus and NYCC. Jarraya et al. [92] developed OCV-RLS fusion algorithm for finding SOC of hybrid supercapacitors. SOC estimator is based on the combination of the OCV offline method and two algorithms RLS and EKF. Experimentation shows that SOC estimating tool formed with Python-Rasberry is simple, accurate, and robust to handle dynamic applications such as changes in charge–discharge modes and dynamic changes of SC output voltage. Li et al. [93] presented a combined approach using an extreme learning machine (ELM) model for predicting the RUL of supercapacitors. The result shows that the HKF-ELM model gives 77.62% improved performance than the ELM model. The Performance of HKF-ELM is enhanced than the PSO-ELM model, Kalman filter, and KA-ELM model by 77.46%, 87.40%, and 82.51% respectively. HKF-ELM model can guarantee high prediction accuracy and realize fast operation. Nanda et al. [94] have studied a correlation between features of SCs like electrode type, material composition, morphology, etc and cyclic stability of SCs using ML algorithms. The authors used PCA and attribute prioritization for feature selection. Further prediction of performance in terms of the cyclic stability of SC is done with WEKA. Some of the key features for prediction of cyclic stability are 3D structure, complete activation of electrode, electrolytes offering more than 2.5 V, etc. The result shows that multiclass classifiers with RF and random committee with random subspace performs better with high accuracy. 4 Conclusions and future perspectives Herein, we comprehensively summarize the application progress of ML in the R & D of supercapacitor materials. As machine learning is a data-driven process, the collection of sufficient quantity and high quality data is a core challenge in order to ensure the accuracy of ML application for supercapacitor materials. The success of ML applications also depends on feature selection. Feature selection can be done by artificial selection or automated feature engineering, later helps to minimize artificial errors. On the basis of physical/chemical, electronic and structural properties, most relevant features are extracted from the chemical dataset. Generalized features used for machine learning applications for supercapacitors are structural features (surface area, pore-volume, etc.), synthesis conditions (doping composition, activation temperature), and operational features (potential window, electron density, current density, electrolyte type, electrolyte concentration, etc.). Among the various ML algorithms, ANN (LM-BP), SVM, MLP, RF, RT, SVM-GWO, XGBoost and SVR are commonly used for the prediction of the capacitance of supercapacitors. It is found that ANN (LM-BP) and MLP give better results with minimal error and hence are used by many researchers for performance prediction. RF and MLP models are also used for finding the relative contribution of input parameters influencing the capacitance of supercapacitor. The structural parameters like SSA, pore size along with doping composition of materials contributed more to the prediction of capacitance, however, the operational parameters such as type of electrolyte and its concentration greatly affects the capacitance. Additionally, ML models can be applied for improved experimental design to minimize time-consuming and laborious repetitive tests on performance optimization tasks. Recently, ensemble methods such as XGBoost and the combinational algorithm SVM-GWO have been used to improve the performance prediction and process optimization of supercapacitors. Neural network-based methods like RNNs, neuro-fuzzy network, DBN-BOHB, ANN are used to predict the remaining lifetime or aging of supercapacitors. Most computational scientists have experimented with precise, efficient, and robust methods like RNNs for estimating the remaining lifetime of supercapacitors. LSTM-RNN performs better with higher prediction accuracy and low error. The error rate is lowered up to 1.61% using the HGA-LSTM hybrid model for precise and robust lifetime estimation. These RNN-based methods provide higher prediction accuracy and also save development time. The supercapacitor performance can be improved by considering the temporal dynamics of the supercapacitor parameters. Interesting patterns can be identified by finding the drift in the parameters. Developing huge and better quality datasets of material properties will boost the forecasting power of the ML model. There is a need to find influential material parameters for better recommendation output. Optimized results for forecasting RUL of SCs with low error can be achieved with the use of implicit deep learning. Further advancement in ML application like quantum enhanced machine learning for improvement in performance prediction accuracy of SCs may be helpful in expediting classical ML techniques. Future research may focus on designing interpretable ML models for predicting supercapacitor performance using emerging techniques like explainable artificial intelligence. We hope this review will facilitate knowledge transfer from the reported research to inspire new ideas for the advancement of ML algorithms for the design and development of high-performance supercapacitors. coredata.dc:description: Supercapacitors are appealing energy storage devices for their promising features like high power density, outstanding cycling stability, and a quick charge–discharge cycle. The exceptional life cycle and ultimate power capability of supercapacitors are needed in the transportation and renewable energy generation sectors. Hence, predicting the capacitance and lifecycle of supercapacitors is significant for selecting the suitable material and planning replacement intervals for supercapacitors. In addition, system failures can be better addressed by accurately forecasting the lifecycle of SCs. Recently, the use of machine learning for performance prediction of energy storage materials has drawn increasing attention from researchers globally because of its superiority in prediction accuracy, time efficiency, and cost-effectiveness. This article presents a detailed review of the progress and advancement of ML techniques for the prediction of capacitance and remaining useful life (RUL) of supercapacitors. The review starts with an introduction to supercapacitor materials and ML applications in energy storage devices, followed by workflow for ML model building for supercapacitor materials. Then, the summary of machine learning applications for the prediction of capacitance and RUL of different supercapacitor materials including EDLCs (carbon based materials), pesudocapacitive (oxides and composites) and hybrid materials is presented. Finally, the general perspective for future directions is also presented.

coredata.dc:title: Machine learning techniques for prediction of capacitance and remaining useful life of supercapacitors: A comprehensive review
